results.title: Water for a city
results.creator_credit: Bruce Moir, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Contrasts the need and the scarcity of water in Australia with the high per capita consumption in our cities. Shows briefly the processes of water supply, pollution control, purification and the variety of uses to which water is put in a city. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Urban patterns
results.creator_credit: Arch Nicholson, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”
A study of the pattern of settlement in Australia, showing how the primacy of the major cities developed and how the economy continues to reinforce their dominance. For schools.

results.title: Man in the desert
results.creator_credit: David Bairstow, Edwin Moses, Keith Gow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Looks at the human geography of our arid zones by examining the lives of Aborigines, cattlemen and miners - men who live in the waste-land of Australia’s deserts. Almost 90% of arid lands are used by someone at some time for some purpose. Questions why man is attracted to the desert. Explains how man has adapted to this environment and what effect this has had on the environment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Bairstow, Edwin Moses, Keith Gow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Landscape: a pattern of change
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Timothy Read and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Landscape can be looked at historically - the present pattern can be seen as the end result of previous land use. The film traces these different patterns through the history of a typical mid-western town in New South Wales, Mudgee.

results.title: Industrial city
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
A study of industrial agglomeration as exemplified by the heavy industry of Newcastle, New South Wales. Establishes the essential industrial base of iron and steel production and the network of associated and supplier industries. Shows the interaction between coal, transport, steel and people. Raises environmental issues and poses a question: when will the agglomeration become uneconomic?

results.title: F for fake = Verites et mensonges
results.creator_credit: Orson Welles, Francois Reichenbach, Dominique Antoine, Janus Film und Fernsehen (Frankfurt), Saci Filmes and Les Films des l'Apostrophe
results.brief_description: Orson Welles stars in and directs this feature/documentary on fake, forgery, art and illusion that well deserves the title, ‘film essay’. As a basis he uses an unfinished documentary (original footage by Francois Reichenbach) on Elmyr de Hory, a noted art forger. Included in Welles’ documentary within a documentary are interviews by Clifford Irving, biographer of de Hory. Welles injects his views on his Hollywood career and artistic originality and presents a short piece in which Pablo Picasso meets a beautiful woman.

results.creator_credit: Malcolm Smith, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Illustrates the five general zones of activity distinguishable in the major cities of Australia, showing the characteristic land use and activities of each.

results.title: Desert landforms
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Shows how planetary circulation systems, rain shadow effects and extremes of temperature away from the sea coasts result in arid or semi-arid deserts in Australia. Describes how water and wind erosion cause typical Australian desert land forms including gorges and eroded rock, salt and clay pans, gibber plains and dunes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Gow, David Bairstow and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Facing the music
results.creator_credit: Robin Anderson, Bob Connolly, Stefan Moore and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A compelling portrait of the struggle endured by Sydney University’s Music Department as it withstands ongoing funding cuts. At the centre of this portrait is Head of the Department, Professor Anne Boyd, a renowned composer in her own right, whose passion for music is matched by her staunch commitment to quality higher education. Boyd’s idealism is what makes her an inspiring, impassioned teacher in the classroom and a fierce defender of education at union meetings and strikes. Filmed over one academic year, “Facing the music” reveals in excruciating detail the sacrifices, emotional strain and tattered morale a university department must endure when faced with sustained cuts. “Facing the music” is made by Australia’s award-winning documentary duo, Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson, who, through capturing this real-life story, force us to consider the wider issue and debate of higher education within a context of economic rationalism. Should students fight for their right to quality education? Should Professors become entrepreneurs to ensure the survival of their academic departments? Should the arts suffer solely because it isn’t designed to sustain commerce and the marketplace? This is an extremely well-crafted, socially pertinent documentary that forces us to consider the role and worth of knowledge, research and the role of the artist in an increasingly hostile world of economic rationalism.
